You profile many individuals who own media and run programming both on radio and television.

And one of the profiles that may be surprising to some people who even follow African-American media is Chauncey Bailey, who's now sadly known as someone who was slain while doing his job as a reporter in Oakland.
But tell us about his broadcast history as well.
Yeah, Chauncey Bailey, many people knew him as just a hard working, crusading journalist who was always for his community in Oakland.
But a lot of people didn't realize that he had strong ties to cable access and television access for African-Americans, and that Oakland was really a leader in this.
They had the first black-owned and controlled cable - local access cable station in the country, I believe.
And that was Soul Beat TV, and was founded in the 1970s, even before BET.
They did, you know, mostly show music videos.
But over the years, it provided an outlet for community issues to be heard.
Chauncey Bailey was actually news director there for eight years, and when it went away, he single-handedly was responsible for resurrecting its tradition.
He founded a new local cable access station called Our TV, which was the successor to Soul Beat.
Now, one of the biggest kahunas is Cathy Hughes, and she's got network Radio One.

station, leaving it with no presence in this huge radio market.

Cathy Hughes is another early pioneer in this.
